Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to step into the exam room. It was a text from my younger brother: “About to try the new trick. Wish me luck!” I glanced at the photo he’d sent—him, helmet askew, grinning at the top of that battered old ramp behind our house. My heart skipped. As his sibling, I felt the urge to call him, to beg him to wait until I could be there, to make sure he was safe. But on the other side of the door, Mrs. Lee was waiting, her eyes red from crying after learning about her diagnosis. She needed me to be present, to answer her questions with patience and empathy, to help her feel less alone. I could almost hear my brother’s laughter, reckless and bright, and I could see Mrs. Lee’s trembling hands. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, pulling me in opposite directions. I stood frozen, torn between the duty to my patient and the instinct to protect my brother, my mind racing with what I should do next.
